12/14

Address: 305 N Zeeb Rd, Ann Arbor, MI 48103
Description: Stalwart eatery for German & American dishes decked with antique steins & photos, plus beer garden.

summary.snippet: "Service is good as is the home baked bread served as an appetizer."
"Minimal vegetarian options but a nice selection of dish/seafood."
"Promo seating, friendly and helpful staff, serve great beer and food."

most_relevant.description: Wow! One of the best places I’ve eaten post covid. The food tastes like it came out of your grandmas kitchen. Real ingredients, real food and the price was just right. I enjoyed everything I had from the chocolate martini to the stuffed cabbage and schnitzel and noodles. It is decorated so cute and the staff is inviting. Very with the visit in the small town of Dexter

On an unplanned trip to Ann Arbor I stumbled upon this place, and now I can’t wait to return one day.  The food was authentic and delicious, the beer tasty and generously poured.  My server made me feel like I was a valued guest in her home.  It was just all around a terrific experience.  I highly recommend!

We’ve been going here for past 26 years- - 2x a year, Fall and once in the winter- Over the past handful of years, I noticed a quality change in some of the food items- Prices of course have increased greatly but for most part I thought they were keeping portions the same-

My husband usually gets the rolled up tender beef with pickles, which is still prepared terrifically, but seem to be getting smaller- We even thought way back years go, you got three or maybe they were just much bigger- $25 is about our cap- his German potato salad and red cabbage were tasty

I got the Copenhagen schnitzel- Two very large, well prepared, tender pieces of fried veal with a Swiss cheese sour cream sauce- Truly, without the lemon the sauce was bland- My cabbage and mashed potatoes were tasty $25

We thought the mashed potato and cabbage sides seemed to be smaller servings…Service was ok- Nothing bad but not engaging or extra- She took our meal orders , brought us our food and the bill- I don’t know if we will make a winter trip, this year- It’s quite a drive - We’re older and although a tasty meal it didn’t leave me looking forward to the next visit-

This is a good place - period.  Had the scheinhaxe (pock hock) and it was excellent and close to what is actually served in Germany.  The Wife had the schnitzel and that was really good too.  The side salad with blue cheese was extremely fresh and full of dark leafy greens and not just pointless iceberg.  Great that they have Franziskaner hefeweizen on tap too!  Waitress was very kind.   Interior was very nice with an appropriate old German feel (AND CLEAN!!!).  Highly recommended.

Stopped by because of the sign on the highway. The food is great, the waitress was so friendly, attentive to every table, and informational. The chocolate torte was the star with the texture somewhere between a ganache and a flourless chocolate cake. I would go back just for the desserts. The wursts are all fine ground and rather spongy, which usually isn’t what I’d go for but they were delicious nonetheless. We had the haus platter for two between two people. It could honestly feed four.

Edit: Went again and the soups are consistently delicious. The potato pancakes were crispy and paired well with applesauce. The strudel and bread pudding was good, but not worth coming out here for like the chocolate torte. If a dessert doesn’t specify homemade, they brought it in but made locally. The house special sauerbraten was unfortunately and surprisingly not good. It traditionally uses a tough cut of meat and it shows. Tough, dry, and a little reminiscent of cat food. No amount of marinating can save eye of round when it’s cooked this hard.

If you’re interested in trying German food, this is a good place to go. We had no wait to sit down on 6pm on Sunday. The waitress was very hurried the entire time, rushing us during ordering and throughout the evening. We ordered and food came out quickly. The salmon pasta was just average at best. However, the potato pancakes were perfectly crispy and well balanced. My husband rated the Reuben a 4/5, he’s had better but would order it again. Overall, prices are quite steep for the amount and flavor of the food. Overall, not a horrible experience, but likely not a place we would return to again.
Food was great.  We ordered the bratwurst platter and prime rib dinners.  First time visit.

Having eaten homemade German food for the past 60 years, I found the spaezle and pork cutlet a little disappointing. However, the red cabbage and French onion soup were winners.

It has been 30 years since my last visit. The German decor is still great even though the location has changed.
